Text: Ukraine's membership on the agenda at Nato summit But the meeting in Lithuania will see disagreement on what to promise President Zelensky.
Summarized_Data: – NATO leaders are gathering in Lithuania for a crucial summit that could shape the direction of the war in Ukraine and the future of the Western alliance. They arrive with a welcome boost after Turkey dropped its objections to Sweden joining the alliance. But after late night talks on Monday, he announced that Turkey had agreed to support Sweden's application to join NATO. On the membership issue, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky wants Nato to say Ukraine could join as soon as possible after the fighting ends - setting out explicitly how and when this could be achieved. But some Nato nations are reluctant to go too far, fearing the promise of near-automatic membership could give Russia an incentive both to escalate and drag out the war. Over their two-day summit, Nato leaders are expected to agree new plans to deter and defend the alliance against future Russian aggression by beefing up their forces in the east. Some Nato members will promise Ukraine new security guarantees. But perhaps most importantly, some members are expected to set out more explicitly Ukraine's pathway to joining the alliance.

Text: Palestinian boy shot in Jenin was unarmed - family It comes after videos emerge of the moment the 16-year-old was killed during an Israeli assault.
Summarized_Data: – Israel said all the Palestinians who were killed were combatants. But the videos show Abdul Rahman Hassan Ahmad Hardan, 16, was unarmed when he was shot. The teenager was shot in the head outside al-Amal hospital on the second day of the military incursion, which Israel said was intended to root out a "safe haven of terrorism" in Jenin refugee camp. Israel Defense Forces spokesman Lt Col Richard Hecht, asked by the BBC last week about the casualties, said: "There were 12 people killed, every one that was killed was involved directly with terrorism." After his death, Abdul Rahman Hardan was claimed as a member by the Palestinian militant group Islamic Jihad. But his family has distanced itself from the claim, and Israel has yet to show evidence he posed a threat at the time he was fatally shot. Under international law, the use of firearms by security forces against civilians is defined as a measure of last resort, and can only take place to stop an "imminent threat of death or serious injury."

Text: 'All hands on deck' as floods deluge US north-east Crews from several US states converge on Vermont where towns have been cut off by the inundation.
Summarized_Data: – A woman in her 30s died in New York state as flood waters swept through streets on Sunday. She was trying to flee her home with her dog for safety. "She crossed with a pet and lost her footing and unfortunately was washed away down into a ravine," an official for Orange County, New York, official told NBC News. More intense rainfall is forecast for far north-eastern New York state and parts of northern Vermont. Flash flooding from excessive rainfall was expected across New England until Tuesday morning with Vermont facing the highest risk, forecasters said. The NWS warned much of Vermont to be on alert for "catastrophic flooding that has not been seen in this part of the country since 2011."

Text: Aretha Franklin sons contest will found under sofa Five years after the Queen of Soul died without a known will, her heirs are in court over her estate.
Summarized_Data: – When Aretha Franklin died from pancreatic cancer in August 2018, it was thought that she had left behind no will for an estate worth millions. But months later, handwritten wills were found in a cabinet and under a sofa cushion at her home in suburban Detroit, Michigan. A jury will now determine which of two documents should be ruled as the Queen of Soul's valid last testament. The trial began on Monday and is expected to last less than a week. The dispute had earlier driven Ms Owens to quit as representative of her aunt's estate.

Text: Senate abortion row leaves Marines leader in limbo An Alabama senator has held up 265 nominations over a Pentagon policy ensuring access to abortion.
Summarized_Data: – The US Marine Corps has no confirmed commandant for the first time in more than a century and a half as a Republican senator's abortion protest blocks over 200 military appointments. Top military nominations are approved by the Senate Armed Services committee and eventually the full chamber, but a single senator can hold up the process. Since February Senator Tommy Tuberville has refused to confirm nominees. The Pentagon says 265 nominations have been affected by the row. Until formally approved, the acting commandant of the Marine Corps cannot issue guidance on planning or policies, nor make major changes. Senator Tuberville of Alabama is protesting against a Pentagon policy that offers travel allowances and time off for military personnel who need an abortion. The US Marine Corps has no confirmed commandant for the first time in more than a century and a half as a Republican senator's abortion protest blocks over 200 military appointments.

Text: Watch: What's next in BBC presenter claims?
Summarized_Data: – The BBC still has many questions to answer after lawyers representing the young person at the center of the allegations disputed the mother's account. In a letter to the BBC, the lawyer makes claims that throw doubt on the story that has dominated front pages through the weekend, but with the BBC facing the media as it presents its annual report, the corporation's director general can expect the event to be dominated by the crisis.

Text: How TikTok fuels human smuggling at the US border
Summarized_Data: – It's like Christmas for these smugglers right now," Mr Calderon told the BBC, adding that there is a perception among many migrants that successfully crossing the border without being detained is more difficult. Experts say these video clips—on platforms including TikTok, YouTube and WhatsApp—are the public face of a highly sophisticated, multi-billion dollar illegal industry that has taken advantage of confusion over changes in US immigration policies to spread disinformation and drive demand for their services. Current and former law enforcement sources in the US and Mexico estimated that typical prices are now around $15,000, rising to between $50,000 and $60,000 for many migrants.

Text: Brad makes Pitt stop at Silverstone for F1 movie
Summarized_Data: – Brad Pitt was seen in costume at Silverstone during the British Grand Prix weekend. The star, and co-star Damson Idris, were spotted in white and black racing suits on the grid at the Northamptonshire circuit on Sunday. Pitt, 59, told Sky Sports he was "a little giddy right now." The Oscar-winner is playing the role of a veteran driver returning to the grid after a 30-year absence. The film is being made in collaboration with F1, providing the project with special access to racetracks and drivers. Pitt and Idris in racing suits represented the fictional APXGP team as they mingled among real F1 drivers at Silverstone. As well as the film crew's presence on Sunday, Pitt was seen strolling among the crowds on Thursday and filming also took place on the track during breaks in actual racing.

Text: Snowhannesburg: Rare fall stuns South Africans
Summarized_Data: – People have woken up to snow and sleet in South Africa's biggest city, Johannesburg, for the first time in over a decade. South Africans are being warned to keep warm as a cold front sweeps across most of the country. "No major disruptions have been caused by the snowfall at this stage," a spokesman for the South African Weather Service (Saws) has told the BBC. Cold weather conditions are expected to continue through the week. Many people in Johannesburg on Monday seem enchanted by the rare sight of snow in their city.
